column1: alohaspaceman 160952192001 "2017-05-22 16:50:04 GMT" https://alohaspaceman.tumblr.com/post/160952192001/how-alex-oloughlin-found-his-aloha-spirit "  It was early 2010 and the Australian actor had just been offered the lead role on the reboot of the classic crime drama Hawaii Five-0
column2: stepping into the shoes of the legendary Jack Lord to play the 50th stateâ€™s taciturn top cop
column3: Steve McGarrett. Accepting meant moving to Oahu
column4: in the center of the planetâ€™s loveliest island archipelago. It should have been a no-brainer. Cue that big wave and the theme song by the Ventures:Dum-duh-da-da-da-dumâ€¦â€œI was conflicted
column6: reflecting on the decision from his house in Waikikiâ€™s idyllic Diamond Head. â€œIâ€™d done two network shows before that
column7: neither of which had gone past a season.â€ Heâ€™d played vampire/private investigator Mick St. John on the short-lived 2007 supernatural romance Moonlight. A year later
column8: he was Dr. Andy Yablonski on the medical drama Three Rivers
column9: canceled after just eight episodes. Though anything seemed better than being penniless in Los Angeles
column10: to suffer through another failed show in the middle of the Pacific
column13: was a risk he wasnâ€™t sure he wanted to take.â€œI didnâ€™t know anything about Hawaii. I asked everyone
column14: â€˜What do I do? Is this the right move?â€™â€ Oâ€™Loughlin says. â€œEverybody was like
column15: 'Are you crazy? Whatâ€™s wrong with you?â€™â€He took the gig
column16: staying on Waikiki Beach. For fans of the show
column17: thatâ€™s where McGarrett and partner Danny â€œDannoâ€ Williams were recently snookered into a joint spa weekend with their significant others.    â€œIt was beautiful
column18: but I didnâ€™t get to see the real Hawaii
column19: â€ O'Loughlin says. â€œI got a glimpse of something that wasnâ€™t what Hawaii is. The weird
column21: crazy hotel part. I still didnâ€™t know how I felt about it
column22: but the pilot felt really good.â€It was
column24: a really good pilot. In the nail-biting prelude
column25: naval commander McGarrettâ€™s convoy comes under rocket fire in the mountains of South Korea by baddies out to free his arms-dealer prisoner
column27: McGarrett listens on his satellite phone as his father
column29: is killed on Oahu by Antonâ€™s brother
column30: Victorâ€”though not before the Honolulu Police Department veteran leaves his son a few cryptic last words.By the time that wave breaks and the opening credits roll
column31: youâ€™re hooked: McGarrett has a vendetta and a mystery to solve
column32: and youâ€™re coming along with him. Reboots are tough
column34: coupled with O'Loughlinâ€™s chiseled portrayal of McGarrett
column35: made the 21st century Hawaii Five-0 an instant hit. Suddenly
column36: Oahu started feeling more certain.â€œPeople say these islands either embrace you or push you away
column37: â€ O'Loughlin says. â€œI found myself
column38: as a gift from the islands
column39: being blessed in and given a Hawaiian name. I found all sorts of things drawing me in deeper and deeper.â€    With a full season to shoot
column40: he started to learn the local rhythms from friends
column41: like fellow cast member Daniel Dae Kim
column42: whose knowledge of Oahu stretches back to his days filming Lost. He took up surfing. A few years in
column43: he flew in some friends from back home in Australia to help him rebuild a midcentury modern home heâ€™d found in Diamond Head that had â€œspectacular bones.â€Then he met the Hawaiian surfer and model Malia Jones. The couple had a son
column46: and later married. The house filled with boys. O'Loughlin brought to the family his teenage son
column48: and Jones brought a son from a previous marriage
column49: Spike.â€œIâ€™m about to use the G word to embrace the scope
column50: â€ O'Loughlin says. â€œI donâ€™t know whatâ€™s out there. I donâ€™t know whether thereâ€™s a God or whether thereâ€™s lots of gods or whether thereâ€™s just universal energy
column51: but I know from whatâ€™s happened that thereâ€™s something bigger than me.â€As O'Loughlinâ€™s life was progressing on Oahu
column53: albeit down a much rockier family path. He avenged the death of his father. His mother
column55: believed to be dead for 20 years
column57: having faked her death to escape threats from her CIA past.He vanquished his true nemesisâ€”the nefarious crime boss Wo Fatâ€”who over the course of seasons framed him for the murder of Hawaiiâ€™s governor
column59: and revealed himself to be McGarrettâ€™s virtual half-brother. Heâ€™s had two romantic relationships and has spent a lot of time shirtless and even more time kicking sundry bad guy ass.Hawaii Five-0 seasons are epicâ€”each a whopping 25 episodes. Multiply that by six and you wind up at Episode 150. Playing a character for that long does things to you. O'Loughlin is in territory where few actors ever get to tread. â€œItâ€™s such a massive volume
column60: â€ he says. â€œThis has been a master class for me. I can definitely drop into McGarrettâ€™s head space anytime. I have a bible of who he is in my soul
column61: in my mind.â€With Wo Fat and his family issues somewhat in the rearview
column62: McGarrett seems to be finding a modicum of peace on the show. â€œThis season has been more of an easy-peasy McGarrett
column63: â€ Oâ€™Loughlin says. â€œHe still misses his dad
column64: and the thing with Doris still hasnâ€™t totally left him. But itâ€™s not all like
column65: 'Argh! Iâ€™ve got to save the world!â€™â€Still
column66: O'Loughlin is happy to leave the character behind when shooting wraps. â€œHeâ€™s a proper tough guy and a Navy SEAL. Heâ€™s always ready to go
column68: 'What are we doing? What do we got?â€™ Iâ€™ve had the great fortune of being exposed to a lot of Navy SEALs
column69: whoâ€™ve helped me with the character. Theyâ€™re terrific guys. But being like them requires a specific sort of energy
column70: and I have to manufacture that energy
column71: â€ he says. â€œAt the end of the day itâ€™s like
column72: 'Keep calm and have another cold one.â€™â€    Paradise hasnâ€™t been all surf and breathtaking sunsets. McGarrett may be a SEAL and a Teflon super-cop
column74: and injuries have taken their toll. In the first few seasons
column75: he elected to do most of his own stunts
column76: which he says was a mistake. He rattles off a litany of fractures and lacerations that could rival a snapshot collection of charts in any emergency room.â€œI blew one of my knees
column81: â€ he says. â€œIâ€™ve knocked my front teeth out. Iâ€™ve got fake front teeth. I tore my right shoulder to piecesâ€”three external tears
column82: a labrum tear and a detachment of the bicep tendon. My current favorite injury is two herniated discs in my lower lumbar
column83: which Iâ€™m receiving stem cell treatment for to avoid surgery.â€That last injury spooked O'Loughlin. Always athletic
column84: he had to give up everything except swimming. The pain was so great
column85: he could barely rouse himself from bed
column86: and he worried about being able to throw a football with his grandkids.Signed on to Hawaii Five-0 through eight seasons
column87: he began talking about walking away while he felt he still could. But recently
column89: and those stem cell injections? Theyâ€™ve been â€œmagic
column90: â€ he says. Does this mean he might challenge Jack Lordâ€™s record 12 seasons as McGarrett?â€œThat would be a miracle
column91: â€ Oâ€™Loughlin says with a laugh. â€œBut I can see coming back and doing another season or two. I think this show is everything. Itâ€™s the core of it all.â€One thing is certain: O'Loughlin has found his home.â€œThe majority of my important memories are now Hawaiian memories
column92: â€ he says. â€œYouâ€™ve just got to look around. Youâ€™ve just got to watch the waves in the winter here. Thereâ€™s something bigger than me in the world
column93: and I feel like that source or whatever that is had something to do with this whole journey for me
column94: because now it all makes sense.â€By Ryan Devlin | Photography by Nino MuÃ±oz | Styled by Lily Unkhoff.Originally published in Watch! Magazine
